Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Story:
I sat at my desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, the gentle hum of my laptop filling the quiet room. My mind was tangled in the logic of a module I’d been meaning to refactor—there was time, the deadline was generous, but the code was messy, and it gnawed at me. I wanted to do it right, to make it clean and efficient, to live up to the standards I set for myself as a developer.

But then I heard the soft sigh from the living room. My spouse sat curled on the couch, eyes distant, worry etched across their face. I knew I should go to them, ask what was wrong, share my own work frustrations, and listen—really listen. That’s what we promised each other: open communication, no matter how busy life got.

I felt the pull from both sides—my need to perfect the code, to not leave a job half-done, and my promise to be present, to be a partner who cares and communicates. My heart thudded with the weight of both expectations, and I sat frozen, torn between the screen and the person I love, unsure which role to answer first.
